intro: Haenianthus incrassatus, commonly known as the thickened rock sandwort, is a perennial flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the family Montiaceae and is characterized by its compact growth habit and fleshy, succulent leaves. The plant produces small, clustered flowers that are typically white or pale pink, blooming in late spring to early summer. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is often found in coastal or arid environments. Due to its hardy nature, it is sometimes cultivated in rock gardens or as a decorative plant in dry landscapes.
